content:
I think I need some slight sanity check. Does the following look correct: when someone says 2d+O(1)=(2+o(1))d2^d + O(1) = (2 + o(1))^d2d+O(1)=(2+o(1))d, what they actually mean is

∀f∈O(1),∃g∈o(1),2d+f(d)=(2+g(d))d\forall f \in O(1), \exists g \in o(1), 2^d + f(d) = (2 + g(d))^d∀f∈O(1),∃g∈o(1),2d+f(d)=(2+g(d))d

I am worried that I misplaced the ∀\forall∀ and ∃\exists∃ quantifiers. Both being ∀\forall∀ is definitely wrong, and both being ∃\exists∃ seems wrong.

Yes. In general, you replace === by ∈\in∈ or ⊆\subseteq⊆ (depending on whether only the RHS or both sides contain asymptotic notation) to get a "formal" version (where O(1)O(1)O(1) denotes the set of bounded functions and o(1)o(1)o(1) denotes the set of functions tending to zero), which in this case specializes to what you wrote.
Gareth Ma has marked this topic as resolved.

It seems that the definition above is actually slightly incorrect for rather stupid reasons. Say we want to write n−1=o(n)2n - 1 = o(n)^2n−1=o(n)2 (both sides as functions N→R\mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{R}N→R), then the discussion above means we write it as ∃g∈o(n),n−1=g(n)2\exists g \in o(n), n - 1 = g(n)^2∃g∈o(n),n−1=g(n)2, but this is not true, since no such ggg satisfies g(0)2=−1g(0)^2 = -1g(0)2=−1. I think the correct way to write this is n−1=f[l]g(n)2n - 1 =^f[l] g(n)^2n−1=f[l]g(n)2 where lll is the Filter, so here it's (implicitly) atTop.

Screenshot-2024-03-20-at-16.05.25.png

The text is wrapped horribly, apologies...

I'm not sure writing o(n)2o(n)^2o(n)2 for the set of functions of the form g2g^2g2 for g∈o(n)g \in o(n)g∈o(n) is standard notation, though. I would expect it to mean o(g)⋅o(g)o(g) \cdot o(g)o(g)⋅o(g) (that is, a product of two possibly different functions in o(g)o(g)o(g)).
But that probably contradicts my earlier message
I agree that requiring it only for large enough n is better
I don't interpret o(1)2o(1)^2o(1)2 as o(1)⋅o(1)o(1) \cdot o(1)o(1)⋅o(1) (although they happen to be the same thing). What's the analogous interpretation of (1+o(1))n(1 + o(1))^n(1+o(1))n?
(Or, more simply, o(1)100o(1)^{100}o(1)100?)
o(1)100=o(1)o(1)^{100}=o(1)o(1)100=o(1), and (1+o(1))1000=1+o(1)(1+o(1))^{1000}=1+o(1)(1+o(1))1000=1+o(1).

If f(n)=(1+o(1))nf(n) = (1 + o(1))^nf(n)=(1+o(1))n means "there is an o(1)o(1)o(1) function ggg such that f(n)=(1+g(n))nf(n) = (1 + g(n))^nf(n)=(1+g(n))n"

Then f(n)=o(1)2f(n) = o(1)^2f(n)=o(1)2 should mean "there is an o(1)o(1)o(1) function ggg such that f(n)=g(n)2f(n) = g(n)^2f(n)=g(n)2". Not "there are two o(1)o(1)o(1) functions g1,g2g_1, g_2g1​,g2​ such that f(n)=g1(n)g2(n)f(n) = g_1(n) g_2(n)f(n)=g1​(n)g2​(n)". Never mind that these are equivalent for nonnegative fff.

Basically, I agree that the correct way to fix this is to look at the germ of the function, rather than allowing o(1)2o(1)^2o(1)2 to mean the product of two possibly different functions that are both o(1)o(1)o(1).

o(1)o(1)o(1), O(f)O(f)O(f) and the likes are to be understood as similar to ideals in rings which have two distinct stability properties: addition and multiplication by any element. (Here it's multiplication by stuff which is bounded around the point.) Consequently, algebraic operations such as products and powers are to be understood as the “ideal” generated by the kind of objects. If I,JI, JI,J are ideals of a ring RRR, then I⋅JI\cdot JI⋅J is the ideal generated by all products ababab, for a∈Ia\in Ia∈I and b∈Jb\in Jb∈J; and InI^nIn is the ideal generated by all products a1…ana_1\dots a_na1​…an​, where these elements belong to III.
